utterances: Tomorrow on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED, I'll talk with Roxana Saberi in her first major interview since her release and her return to the United States.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
In today's consumer health news, how you track your health.
A new survey shows doctors like the idea of annual physicals.
That doesn't sound surprising until you learn that a respected medical task force found no evidence the exams do any good.
NPR's Joanne Silberner talked to doubters and believers in the annual physical.
Thirty-five-year-old Greg Fedder(ph) is a believer in annual physicals.
On a recent summer afternoon, the Washington lawyer was waiting in his doctor's office for his yearly checkup.
There's this kind of, you know, your whole body falls apart after 30 kind of thing.
So I just figured that it's time to start paying attention.
At one annual physical, he found out he had an elevated cholesterol of 272.
There's not way that you would find something out like that without, you know, routine checkups.
I had no indications that I, you know, had any problems and I'm not aware of a family history and, you know, I otherwise felt fine.
Fedder's doctor is Alan Pocinki.
Pocinki also thinks annual physicals are a good idea.
It helps build a doctor-patient relationship, that seeing people at least once a year, you get to know them, they get to know you.
They feel more comfortable coming in with a small problem before they let it get to be a big problem.
You feel more comfortable maybe handling small problems on the phone.
Fedder's last physical was a little more than a year ago.
After about a 20-minute wait, Dr. Pocinki comes in.
So how are you?
I'm doing OK.
All right.
Well, I'm sorry to hear that you're still having so many issues with ongoing back pain.
Fedder has some good news.
I've been eating better, exercising...
It looks like you lost a little weight.
...taking the Lipitor.
Have you lost a little weight?
I have...
Yeah.
...yeah, about 20 pounds.
Yeah.
And his headaches are under control.
That's good.
And then The Landshark, it's the most organic, really, from Ole Miss because we had a player with the name of Tony Fein who passed away last year, but they started calling the defense Landsharks.
And so that was kind of a way to get the defense pumped up.
And they would hold their hand to their forehead in a shark fin-type thing, and that would mean fins up.
So whenever we make big plays on defense, you can see the crowd doing fins up.
And we'll play ""Jaws"" music, and there's a lot of stuff that goes along with the Landsharks.
And the crowd really loves it, and it gets everybody pumped up.
Okay.
So three finalists, all with close connections to the hearts of Ole Miss fans.
And speaking of Ole Miss fans, we should mention, before they get too upset, that the sports teams will still be called The Rebels.
This is an issue of appearances that you're sorting through, the mascot on the sidelines and what...
Yeah, exactly.
It's a...
...that would look like.
That's one of the main things we try to stress, because we do hold all of our traditions so closely.
But does it sidestep the issue a little bit?
I mean, the word rebels could be construed by people as a reference to the Confederacy.
True.
And - yeah.
But I think if, you know, if we do whatever this new mascot is, I think it more preserves rebels because it takes a little heat of that issue, if that makes sense.
Not really.
Walk with through that.
Well, I mean, I - we've been - we're always going to be the Ole Miss Rebels.

We've been talking with Ty New.
He's a senior at Ole Miss, and he's co-chair of the mascot selection committee.
Several factors mitigated the destructive power of that earthquake.
It struck offshore deep down about 21 miles underground.
It was centered about 70 miles from the nearest city, Concepcion.
By contrast, the earthquake that devastated Haiti was much closer to the earths surface and was very close to the capital, Port-au-Prince.
But there is another factor that has kept the loss of life in Chile much lower than in Haiti, and that is much stronger buildings.
Eduardo Kausel specializes in earthquake engineering at MIT and he says the philosophy of building codes has been changing.
The philosophy of earthquake codes until relatively recently was to prevent the loss of life, in other words to prevent the collapse of buildings or houses.
That philosophy now is changing.
And in addition to protecting people, we are now also trying to protect the buildings themselves.
Because if you have a big earthquake you lose many buildings, you lose many bridges, et cetera, as a result of which the economic impact on the country can be phenomenal actually.
And what would be in those codes exactly?
What would they say if you want to design an earthquake-proof building, heres what you have to do?
What would it say?
Well, you start with the materials and there are choices of materials in Chile.
For the most part they use - for high-risk buildings they use concrete, reinforced concrete or reinforced concrete and steel.
But on the other hand you have materials which are very poor for an earthquake country, and that would be adobe for example.
We were just hearing about the 15-story building in Concepcion that collapsed.
So clearly this is not failsafe, these codes that youre talking about or else that building may have been poorly constructed.
That may be so.
I saw the video, it was far too poor for me to make an assessment as to why it toppled over.
There can be any number of reasons.
I mean it may have to do with the foundation, it may have to do with the soil that somehow liquefied or poor construction, poor materials.
I mean just by looking very briefly at the video I couldnt really tell.
What did it look like to you, that building?
Well, it seemed that it failed at the foundation level because the whole building rotated as a rigid body actually.
When youre designing earthquake proof or earthquake resistant buildings, what are you trying to do?
What are you trying to get that building to do when it responds to shaking?
Well, you would like to make sure that the building will not fail and youre trying to achieve that by making what the engineers call a ductile -ductility.
Ductility is - its very easy to explain.
I mean, you take a paper clip and you bend it back and forth, and it doesnt break.
On the other hand, you take a piece of chalk, which is brittle, and you bend a little bit and it breaks immediately.
So, concrete in principle is also brittle material but by adding adequate amounts of steel you can make it ductile.
When you heard about what had happened and you thought about what would be happening in Chile - which is where you're from - what did you imagine?
What did you picture?
